item.title: Trump Calls on Netflix to Oust Susan Rice From Its Board
item.description: The president made the attack as Netflix and Paramount Skydance face a key deadline in a bidding war for Warner Bros. Discovery.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:description: Susan Rice, who worked in the Clinton, Biden and Obama administrations, joined the Netflix board in 2018, left in 2020 to work in the Biden administration, and then joined again in 2023.

item.title: Trump Aides Project Confidence on Tariffs After Court Loss
item.description: Administration officials maintain that they can replicate the sky-high duties recently invalidated by the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm, Alan Rappeport and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Through a new 15 percent global tariff that President Trump announced on Saturday, the administration looked to project confidence that the legal setback would not deter its brinkmanship on trade.

item.title: They Did Deals With Trump to Get Lower Tariffs. Now They Are Stuck.
item.description: Countries that under the threat of tariffs made commitments like enormous investment pledges face the reality that they might have been better off waiting.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and River Akira Davis
item.media:description: President Trump and Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi of Japan signing trade and mineral deals in Tokyo in October.

item.title: Should I Tell My Housekeeper, ‘I’m Here for You’?
item.description: Plus, what to do when your job interviewer spouts off on things better left unsaid.
item.dc:creator: Max Read
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Margeaux Walter for The New York Times

item.title: Trump’s Challenge to Free Market Capitalism
item.description: Stakes in private companies. Handshake deals with chief executives. The president’s economic policy has drifted far from principles that long defined the Republican Party. Is it capitalism at all?
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman

item.title: A Roving Reporter on the Future of Transit in New York City
item.description: “A lot of interesting things happening in the city involve how people get around,” said Stefanos Chen, a Metro reporter and lifelong bus aficionado.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stefanos Chen, a former real estate reporter, covers New York City’s mass transit for the Metro desk at The Times.

item.title: New York Nurses’ Strike Ends After 6 Weeks as Last Holdouts Approve Deal
item.description: Workers at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia hospital voted for a contract with raises and layoff protections, meaning more than 4,000 nurses will return.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: At its height, the strike by New York City nurses included nearly 15,000 workers.

item.title: Traveling This Weekend? Here’s What to Know About the Snowstorm.
item.description: A major winter storm on Sunday and Monday is expected to bring delays and cancellations across much of the Northeast.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Hiltner and Kim Bhasin
item.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis for The New York Times
item.media:description: An industrial snow-melting machine at LaGuardia Airport in New York after a major snowstorm in January.

item.title: Trump’s Trade Gamble Will Continue, Despite Supreme Court Rebuke
item.description: The president seems as intent on tariffs as ever and argues that his trade agenda is succeeding, despite little evidence to support it
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump signed an executive order in April that imposed tariffs on countries around the world. The Supreme Court ruled on Friday that Mr. Trump had exceeded his authority.

item.title: JPMorgan Admits to Debanking Trump After Jan. 6 Capitol Attacks
item.description: Nation’s largest bank, in response to a lawsuit filed by the president, confirmed his longstanding complaint about “debanking.”
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: The JPMorgan Chase headquarters in Midtown Manhattan late last year.

item.title: Trump Says He Will Raise Global Tariff to 15 Percent
item.description: The move signaled that the president would press ahead with steep global import taxes despite the legal setback from the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump said on social media that the new, global tariff of 15 percent would take effect immediately.

item.title: Six Questions on the Future of Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: The Supreme Court’s ruling on the president’s tariffs has jolted Washington and the business world. Here’s what to watch next.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Michael J. de la Merced, Bernhard Warner and Vivienne Walt
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court dealt a major blow yesterday to President Trump’s tariff-driven trade policy.

item.title: Inside the Big Tech Lobbying Machine Aiming to Halt Social Media Bans
item.description: Tech giants, including Meta and Alphabet, are spending lavishly on splashy billboard ads, courting on-the-fence politicians and bulking up their ranks of lobbyists.
item.dc:creator: Vivienne Walt
item.media:credit: Ksenia Kuleshova for The New York Times
item.media:description: The biggest tech companies are bolstering their lobbying efforts in Europe as several countries weigh teen social media bans.

item.title: For India, Buying Russian Oil Just Got More Complicated
item.description: India’s prime minister acceded to many of President Trump’s demands under pressure of heavy tariffs. It would be awkward to reject them now.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and President Trump at the White House in February 2025.

item.title: Fred Segal Has a New Owner. This Time It’s Aritzia.
item.description: The storied Los Angeles retailer, once recognized as an arbiter of West Coast style, has been acquired by the mass-market brand Aritzia.
item.dc:creator: Yola Mzizi
item.category: Fred Segal Home (Los Angeles, Calif, Retailer)
item.media:description: Fred Segal founded his namesake brand in 1961 and opened its first store in Los Angeles that same year. The brand quickly gained attention with the private school set, musicians and mothers and daughters looking to splurge.

item.title: He Researched Dishonesty. He Got Friendly With Jeffrey Epstein.
item.description: Dan Ariely, a behavioral scientist at Duke, sought out the convicted sex offender for his research. Their yearslong correspondence suggests it wasn’t all business.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:description: Dan Ariely, a professor of business administration at Duke University, in 2022.

item.title: Trump Doubles Down on Closing Tax Loophole on Cheap Imports
item.description: The exemption was shut down last year by President Trump based, in part, on the same legal grounds as the tariffs that were invalidated by the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald Trump speaking at the White House on Friday. The de minimis tax loophole had been widely used by companies operating in China to ship goods duty-free to the United States.

item.title: ‘Murky Waters’ for Global Businesses After Trump’s Tariff Loss
item.description: Even after the Supreme Court invalidated many of the president’s levies, foreign leaders and executives assume that U.S. tariffs are here to stay, in one form or another.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
item.media:description: A denim jeans factory in Dong Nai Province, Vietnam.

item.title: With Tariff Changes, Consumers May Be Stuck in a Waiting Game
item.description: Some companies could decide to temper price increases, but the effect would take time to materialize.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember and Jordyn Holman
item.media:description: Economists cautioned that the Supreme Court ruling would probably not lower sticker prices right away, if at all.

item.title: Ask The Morning: The Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.description: The justices struck down a central piece of President Trump’s agenda. What does that mean?
item.dc:creator: the staff of The Morning

item.title: Supreme Court Tariff Ruling to Spur Chaotic Refund Process
item.description: The Trump administration says it could take years and additional litigation for importers to get their money back.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Colby Smith
item.media:description: The Trump administration may have to refund more than $100 billion in tariff revenue to thousands of American importers.

item.title: Businesses Celebrate Tariff Relief, And Brace for New Uncertainty
item.description: The Supreme Court’s ruling against many of President Trump’s tariffs cheered executives who set to work seeking refunds on their duties.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember
item.media:credit: Jimena Peck for The New York Times
item.media:description: Travis Campbell, who owns the luggage manufacturer Eagle Creek, said he hoped to recoup over half a million dollars in tariffs.

item.title: After Tariff Decision, What Happens to Trump’s Deals With China, Canada and Europe?
item.description: The Supreme Court’s decision to invalidate many of President Trump’s tariffs raised questions about what would become of agreements struck with major U.S. trading partners.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher, Meaghan Tobin, Eshe Nelson, Alexandra Stevenson, River Akira Davis, Alex Travelli, Choe Sang-Hun, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Trump signed a trade deal with Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi of Japan in Tokyo in October.

item.title: Tariff Whiplash Clouds Outlook for Federal Budget
item.description: The tariffs thrown out by the Supreme Court had become an important revenue source. President Trump said he could replace that money with other levies.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren

item.title: Christopher S. Wren, Times Bureau Chief in Hostile Lands, Dies at 89
item.description: Over three decades, he reported from Moscow, Beijing, Tehran and elsewhere and wrote well-received books based on his reporting, including one about his globe-trotting cat.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:description: Mr. Wren in an undated photo. Explaining why he went into journalism, he said, “I wanted to find a job where I could go out and satisfy my curiosity and have somebody pay for it.”

item.title: After Supreme Court Loss, Trump Plans to Impose Global Tariffs Using Different Laws
item.description: The administration has been preparing for months for the possibility that the Supreme Court would rule against the president and developed contingency plans.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Using different legal authorities, President Trump plans to impose a 10 percent global tariff and open investigations into certain, unspecified countries’ unfair trade practices.

item.title: Supreme Court Justices Strike Down Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: President Trump was the first to invoke the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977 to set tariffs on imported goods from more than 100 countries.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The tariffs case reached the Supreme Court after three lower courts concluded the taxes were unlawful.

item.title: A Cancer Detection Test Fails in Major Study
item.description: A closely watched clinical trial in Britain that screened blood for early detection of cancer did not show a reduction in diagnoses at later stages of the disease.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Gina Kolata
item.media:description: The Galleri test looks for tiny shards of cancer DNA in the blood.

item.title: U.S. Economy Grew Modestly at End of 2025
item.description: Gross domestic product expanded at a 1.4 percent annual rate in the last quarter of the year, hit by the effects of the government shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Sylvia Jarrus for The New York Times
item.media:description: An auto parts factory in Plymouth, Mich. U.S. economic growth has been strong despite tariffs and uncertainty.

item.title: Is Blue Owl Private Credit’s ‘Canary in the Coal Mine’?
item.description: Steep declines in the shares of private lenders, after a major fund changed how investors can withdraw money, have sparked worries about more trouble to come.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Ian Mount and Vivienne Walt
item.media:description: A big sell-off in the shares of private credit firms has the market on edge.

item.title: Mixed Signals Churn Stock Market Despite Recent Highs
item.description: Major indexes have mostly been treading water for months, as investors’ exuberance for artificial intelligence wears off.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

item.title: Can an A.I. Productivity Boom Clear a Path for More Rate Cuts? Trump’s Fed Pick Thinks So.
item.description: As Federal Reserve chair, Kevin M. Warsh may face a tough task persuading his colleagues to lower borrowing costs because of potential productivity gains.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith and Ben Casselman
item.media:description: Kevin M. Warsh has characterized the A.I. boom as “the most productivity-enhancing wave of our lifetimes — past, present and future.”

item.title: Why the United States Is Seeing an Ongoing Tourism Slump
item.description: Last year, the U.S. was the only major destination to see a decline in international travelers. With increased scrutiny at the border, ICE violence and unpredictable policies, the new year isn’t looking better.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeğinsu
item.category: Disney, Walt, World (Lake Buena Vista, Fla)
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Passengers and crew walk to a Transportation Security Administration security checkpoint at Los Angeles International Airport in November.

item.title: Trump and Indonesia Sign Trade Deal, Locking In 19% Tariffs
item.description: The countries made official an agreement reached last year, with Indonesia avoiding a higher tariff and committing to cooperate on export controls.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: President Prabowo Subianto of Indonesia with President Trump last year.

item.title: Blue Owl Capital Sets Off New Fears About the Private Credit Industry
item.description: The lender’s announcement that investors will no longer be able to ask for a set amount of money back from its funds prompted worries about the private credit industry.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Farrell
item.media:description: Blue Owl Capital, the large private lender, has amassed nearly $300 billion in investor money.

item.title: Trump Administration Uses ‘Equal Time’ Rule to Reshape Late-Night TV
item.description: The F.C.C. is using the “equal time” provision to take aim at hosts like Stephen Colbert. The impact could reshape how talk shows handle politics.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin and Jim Rutenberg
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
item.media:description: Stephen Colbert took “The Late Show” in a more political direction after becoming its host in 2015.

item.title: Labor Secretary’s Husband Barred From Department Premises After Reports of Sexual Assaults
item.description: At least two female staff members said Dr. Shawn DeRemer had touched them inappropriately at the agency in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Evan Gorelick and Rebecca Davis O’Brien
item.media:description: Allegations against Dr. Shawn DeRemer, the husband of Labor Secretary Lori Chavez-DeRemer, were raised as part of an investigation by the Labor Department’s inspector general.

item.title: Some Reese’s Treats Drop the Milk Chocolate. Mr. Reese Disapproves.
item.description: With cocoa prices high, Hershey’s has changed some of its candy recipes. The grandson of the man who invented the original Peanut Butter Cup said he was “embarrassed.”
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown

item.title: Bill Gates Cancels Speech in India Amid Epstein Controversy
item.description: The philanthropist made the announcement on Thursday, after having earlier confirmed his participation in a prominent artificial intelligence summit in India.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Kulish
item.media:description: Bill Gates in January at the annual World Economic Forum meeting in Davos, Switzerland.

item.title: Doing Your Taxes? We Want to Hear From You.
item.description: The New York Times is looking to speak to Americans about how the most recent tax cuts are affecting their pocketbooks.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren

item.title: In 2025, Trade Deficit in Goods Reached Record High
item.description: Data released Thursday by the Census Bureau showed the overall trade deficit with the world narrowed, the result of an expanding trade surplus in services. The trade deficit in goods was the highest on record.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman, Ana Swanson and Keith Collins

item.title: Jittery Markets Seek an Iran ‘Off-Ramp’
item.description: Oil prices spiked and stocks fell as tensions between Washington and Tehran unnerved investors.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:description: The U.S. military presence in the Middle East has been building, putting global markets on edge.

item.title: Walmart Expects Growth Streak to Continue as New Chief Takes Over
item.description: Shoppers are turning to Walmart to stretch their dollars, but an uncertain economy and trade tensions will test the retailer’s new executive team.
item.dc:creator: Kim Bhasin
item.media:description: John Furner took over as Walmart’s chief executive this month.

item.title: Uber Moves to Enact Stricter Background Checks for Drivers
item.description: The New York Times revealed in December that the ride-hailing giant approved drivers with many types of criminal convictions, including violent felonies.
item.dc:creator: Emily Steel
item.media:credit: Joseph Seif for The New York Times
item.media:description: Uber has faced increased scrutiny over its safety record from lawmakers, investors and others.

item.title: Ring’s Founder Knows You Hated That Super Bowl Ad
item.description: Since the commercial aired, Jamie Siminoff has been trying to quell an outcry over privacy concerns with his doorbell cameras.
item.dc:creator: Jordyn Holman
item.media:credit: Jenna Schoenefeld for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jamie Siminoff, who founded Ring, said he understood the privacy concerns stirred by the commercial. But he also feels that more video in the world is better.

item.title: Trump Mulls a North American Trade Pact Without Canada
item.description: U.S. officials are threatening major changes to a trade agreement with Mexico and Canada that could upend the way business is done and leave Canada on the outs.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Money Talks as India Searches for Its Place in Global A.I.
item.description: Narendra Modi, the prime minister, convened foreign leaders, the richest Silicon Valley companies and thousands of Indian entrepreneurs for a week of deal making.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: The India A.I. Impact Summit unfolded across 120 acres in New Delhi this week, featuring more than 300 exhibitors and 500 sessions. Organizers expected about 250,000 participants and visitors.

item.title: Stock Slide and Slow Sales: What’s Happening in China’s E.V. Market?
item.description: Investors are selling shares of Chinese E.V. companies, concerned that intensifying competition and shorter production cycles mean the years of easy growth are over.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Krolik
item.media:credit: Andrea Verdelli for The New York Times
item.media:description: The BYD stand at an auto show in Shanghai last year. BYD’s stock has fallen over 35 percent since its peak last May.

item.title: Defense Department and Anthropic Square Off in Dispute Over A.I. Safety
item.description: How artificial intelligence will be used in future battlefields is an issue that has turned increasingly political and may put Anthropic in a bind.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The Defense Department and Anthropic have been negotiating a contract over A.I. use by the Pentagon.
